name: future value
description: Future value measures how much an amount of money will be worth once compound interest has been added.

clips.name: The Kiss Hello
clips.description: Fifty-three years ago, Jerry's Uncle Leo stiffed Jerry's mother out of $50.  Eager to get it back, Jerry's father says, “Do you know what that's worth today in interest alone? $663.45, figured at a conservative 5% interest, compounded quarterly.”  Morty's calculations are almost accurate, though he does not compound quarterly, and his sum includes the principle, not just the interest.

tags.name: compound interest
tags.description: Compound interest involves adding accumulated interest back to the principal, so that interest is earned on interest from that moment on.

tags.name: future value
tags.description: Future value measures how much an amount of money will be worth once compound interest has been added.

tags.name: present value
tags.description: Present value is the value on a given date of a future payment or series of future payments, discounted to reflect the time value of money.

source.title: Seinfeld
source.description: Seinfeld ran for nine seasons on NBC and became famous as a “show about nothing.” Basically, the show allows viewers to follow the antics of Jerry, George, Elaine, and Kramer as they move through their daily lives, often encountering interesting people or dealing with special circumstances. It is the simplicity of Seinfeld that makes it so appropriate for use in economics courses. Using these clips (as well as clips from other television shows or movies) makes economic concepts come alive, making them more real for students. Ultimately, students will start seeing economics everywhere – in other TV shows, in popular music, and most importantly, in their own lives.
